When this came to the attention of director Peter Jackson, he arranged to have McKenzie reprise the (still-officially-unnamed) character in The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003). In interviews and commentaries, Jackson has informally approved the name of Figwit for the character.
fun_fact_2: Son of actor Peter McKenzie, who plays Elendil in The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001).
fun_fact_3: One half of New Zealand 'folk comedy' duo Flight of the Conchords, with Jemaine Clement.
quote_1: My character is called Lindir, I hang out with Elrond… I’ve got a few lines in Elvish.
quote_2: That's the great thing about Henson's work. He didn't ever play down to children. They just did what they found funny, so the Muppets play amazingly to both adults and kids.
quote_3: I grew up in New Zealand watching The Muppets on TV: never dreamed I'd get to work with them. I was genuinely star struck when I finally met Kermit the frog, but once you get to know him he's just a normal frog, and like many stars here tonight he's a lot shorter in real life.

name: Evangeline Lilly
fun_fact_1: Founded and ran a world development and human rights committee at her university. She has lived in a grass hut in the jungles of the Philippines with a missionary group, and has been a volunteer for children's projects since the age of 14.
fun_fact_2: Has English and Irish ancestry. Her father was raised in Kenya--her paternal grandparents served as missionaries in Africa--and one of her grandmothers was an English war bride.
fun_fact_3: Fluent in French and loves reading, writing, painting, long walks, tea and nature.
quote_1: Even if you're unhappy, just pretend that you're happy. Eventually, your smile will be contagious to yourself. I had to learn that, I used to think, 'I'm being fake,' but you know what? Better to be fake and happy than real and miserable.
quote_2: To his defence, Tolkien was writing in 1937. The world is a different place today. I kept repeatedly telling people that in this day and age, to put nine hours of cinema entertainment in theatres for young girls to go and watch, and not have one female character - it's subliminally telling them that 'You don't matter, you're not important and you're not pivotal to the story'. I think that they were very brave and very right in saying 'We won't do that to the young female audience that will come and watch our films'. And even for women my own age, I think it's time that we stop making stories that are only about men. I love that they make Tauriel a hero.
quote_3: If I didn't try to help others, I'd be no better than the Paris Hiltons of the world, waltzing around with their Louis Vuitton bags and their little dogs. Those people couldn't give a rat's ass if somebody was starving on the street next to them

name: Benedict Cumberbatch
fun_fact_1: Benedict Cumberbatch, in his own words, ”ripped into [his] vocal chords quite literally, [he] had blood at the end of the day from tearing [his] throat to pieces.” in order to get Smaug's voice right.
fun_fact_2: Has central heterochromia as well as sectoral heterochromia, the "groovy" but harmless genetic mutation that his friend James McAvoy describes in X-Men: First Class (2011). Central heterochromia is where each eye has multiple colors - in his case, each has a different but nearly identical combination of blue, green, and gold. Sectoral heterochromia is where one eye has a spot (or sector) of different coloration; his right eye has a brown "freckle" of color that, while small, is typical of sectoral heterochromia.
fun_fact_3: His female fans were originally known as "Cumberbitches", but are now known as the "CumberCollective" or "Cumberpeople". Cumberbatch is uncomfortable with the term "Cumberbitches" because he says its non-inclusive and pejorative
quote_1: [on his look] It's the blessing of having a weird face - somewhere between an otter and something people find vaguely attractive.
quote_2: [On his Hobbit character] It was publicized that I 'voice' Smaug, and I thought, "Fucking hell. My voice, my motions - I worked my arse off to create that dragon!".
quote_3: [on Sherlock (2010) fan-fiction] I suppose my bodily proportions are quite flattering. I'm ripped, doing something I wouldn't normally do with my body, or having done to it, involving Watson. So that's as far as I'll hit about that one, but it's all there on the Web if you want to find it. I was amazed at the level of artistry; people have spent hours doing it. And there's some really weird cross breeding stuff that goes on. The news got out that I was playing Smaug in "Hobbit" and suddenly there were lots of dragons with purple scarves flying around so it's crazy, it's crazy.

name: Mikael Persbrandt
fun_fact_1: Visited the slums of Sao Paulo, Brazil, together with soccer player Zlatan Ibrahimovic for an organization supporting the children's rights.
fun_fact_2: In his youth, he liked playing soccer and boxing. Although hanging around with his "tough" mates, he later applied to the Academy of Ballet in 1983.
fun_fact_3: Visited former child soldiers in Liberia for a Swedish UNICEF campaign against the exploitation of children (2004).
quote_1: [When asked for details prior to the release] It's not that I do not want to say anything, I must not say anything. You have to wait until the film has premiered.
quote_2: For me, acting is a love story. When I’m on stage, it’s an experience of love. I feel alive and good; it’s like therapy.
quote_3: For me, there’s no difference between playing in small or big films. A camera is a camera and a movie set is a movie set – and then there are 700 people at lunch instead of 35

name: Luke Evans
fun_fact_1: He released his debut album At Last on 22 November 2019.
fun_fact_2: He was raised as one of Jehovah's Witnesses, though he left the religion when he was 16 and left school at the same time.
fun_fact_3: Luke Evans' (Bard the Bowman's) performance was dedicated to Paul Walker, with whom he co-starred in Fast & Furious 6 (2013), and who died a few days before this movie's release.
quote_1: Most men have an insecurity of some sort. But we're brought up to believe that we can't show them.
quote_2: I always find cardio the most monotonous. Running on a treadmill shows me why hamsters are so crazy.
quote_3: [When asked about whether might be different to be an openly gay actor in the U.K. than in America?] Well, it depends on how big you are. It's not a big issue, and it's never going to be a big issue for me; whether I'm successful or if I weren't successful, at least I'll never have that skeleton in the closet they can rattle out. Y'know what I mean?

name: Stephen Fry
fun_fact_1: Fry has published four novels as well as a collection of his radio and journalistic miscellanea. He has recorded audiotapes of his novels (an unabridged version of "The Liar" was released in 1995), as well as many other works for both adults and children
fun_fact_2: Stephen Fry (Master of Lake Town) left behind a large supply of alcohol when his scenes wrapped. These were given away as gag prizes when filming wrapped.
fun_fact_3: Despite his fame and charitable efforts, Stephen Fry has been very open and honest about the details of his less than respectable past which includes a brief stint in jail for credit card fraud and 15 years addicted to 'snorting coke' (cocaine). In his recent autobiography he provides a list of places whose owners he offers his deepest apologies to for indulging in his illegal drug habit on the premises, a few of the places on this list were: Buckingham Palace, Windsor Castle, The Houses of Parliament, BBC HQ, ITV HQ and several military bases and headquarters.
quote_1: Homophobia is still a world problem. Homosexuality isn't and never has been. Homosexuals are not interested in making other people homosexual. Homophobics are interested in making other people homophobic.
quote_2: I sometimes wonder if you Americans aren't often fooled by our accent into detecting a brilliance that may not really be there.
quote_3: To be human and to be adult means constantly to be in the grip of opposing emotions, to have daily to reconcile apparently conflicting tensions. I want this, but need that. I cherish this, but I adore its opposite too. I'm maddened by this institution yet I prize it above all others.

name: Ryan Gage
fun_fact_1: The British Independent Film Festival awarded Ryan Best Actor for his performance of Ted Bundy in ANGEL OF DECAY.
fun_fact_2: Ryan Gage is an English actor who has worked in theatre, television, films, and video games.
fun_fact_3: In video games, Gage has portrayed Charibert in the Final Fantasy XIV expansion pack Final Fantasy XIV: Heavensward.
quote_1: I try to find myself in every role I play and I also try to allow them to affect me. That is the way I work. I don’t think we are similar as people but what I do try to do is empathize when I read the scripts and try to find similar moments in my life.
quote_2: It was a dream come true to get on set and to work with Peter Jackson. It was a thrill from start to finish. He is a lovely, lovely man and it was an absolute thrill to be asked to do it.
quote_3: On a very basic level, I learned the basic movie craft on that film. Peter Jackson found it very funny to speak over the loudspeaker and say, “Rule of movie making number three, never do...” [laughs] That amused him enough and embarrassed me a great deal but I still found it very charming!

name: John Bell
fun_fact_1: Bell made his TV debut in 2007 when he played Creet in the episode "Utopia" of Doctor Who after he won the role in a Blue Peter competition.
fun_fact_2: He also played "Young Ian" Murray in the Starz television series Outlander
fun_fact_3: He revealed he was star-struck for the first time when worked with the late Bill Paxton on Hatfield & McCoys.
quote_1: That sort of initial fear that you feel inside can sometimes propel oneself forward.
quote_2: I grew four inches during the entire shoot … I literally did have to bend my knees during some of the shots. But, you know, Peter Jackson has a knack for making tall people small.
quote_3: [When asked if he had any celebrity crushes on set] I fell in love a bit with Evangeline because she is kind of enchanting.

name: Peggy Nesbitt
fun_fact_1: Her father, James Nesbitt, plays Bofur in the series.
fun_fact_2: Peggy and her younger sister, Mary, both moved to New Zealand when their father was cast as Bofur in The Hobbit film trilogy, a role that would require a year of continuous filming.
fun_fact_3: Peggy previously appeared with her father in the 2008 film Blessed.

name: Mary Nesbitt
fun_fact_1: Her father, James Nesbitt, plays Bofur in the series.
fun_fact_2: Mary and her older sister, Peggy, both moved to New Zealand when their father was cast as Bofur in The Hobbit film trilogy, a role that would require a year of continuous filming.

name: Ben Mitchell
fun_fact_1: He won Mr New Zealand in 1999.
fun_fact_2: He was once a personal trainer.
fun_fact_3: Mitchell speaks fluent Te Reo Māori, and lent his support to the Maori Language Week campaigns in 2006 and 2008.
quote_1: Here's how I prepared [for Mr New Zealand]: Step 1 - I decided in my head that I would win. Step 2 - I trained like a gym weirdo for six weeks. Step 3 - I repeated step one. Learned how to catwalk and do interviews. I walked on that stage like I owned it.
quote_2: I don't like bossy people. Men or women. But a bossy man is much easier to deal with than a bossy woman. You'd tell a man chill out or you'd punch him in the head. Clearly, you can't do that to a woman, nor would you want to. A bossy woman reminds a man of a nagging mum. Not cool.
quote_3: I like people to like me, everyone does, and I like people. I'm aware that I disrupt a lot of people because they have too many rules in their head. But there's always going to be scraps on the plate. You don't worry about them. They're for the dog.

name: Simon London
fun_fact_1: His own immersive theatrical brainchild, The Generation of Z, recently completed a three month run in London.
fun_fact_2: Simon has worked in theatre, film, television and radio in Australia, NZ and the UK since '99.
fun_fact_3: Training includes studies with Shakespeare’s Globe, RADA, The Actors Centre and Complicité.

name: Mark Mitchinson
fun_fact_1: He won Best Actor in 2011 for his role as Colin Bower in Screentime's feature film 'Bloodlines".
fun_fact_2: He trained at the Guildhall School of Speech and Drama in London.
fun_fact_3: He has made a name for himself bringing complex and dangerous characters to life on screen.
quote_1: [On working on The Hobbit movies] It’s a totally different perspective and a totally different experience than anything I’d been on before and, you know, I thoroughly enjoyed it.
quote_2: There is so much conversation around Peter Jackson it must be terribly hard for him just to walk into anywhere and, you know, and not for people to have an opinion.
quote_3: [On Peter Jackson] I’d work with him again in a heartbeat.

name: Kelly Kilgour
fun_fact_1: Kelly emerged from a creative background with a BA in Arts (Performance in Theatre & Screen) and MA in Creative Writing (Screenwriting), before transitioning into production and producing roles.
fun_fact_2: Since joining the Models Department at Weta Digital , Kelly has also produced two micro-budget feature films, Chronesthesia and Status Pending.
fun_fact_3: Kelly co-developed, field produced and was the writer on the award winning observational documentary series, Songs From The Inside.

name: Sarah Peirse
fun_fact_1: Peirse’s empathetic performance in ‘Heavenly Creatures’ won the 1995 NZ Film Award for Best Supporting Actress, plus a nomination at America’s Chlotrudis awards.
fun_fact_2: Coached newcomer Melanie Lynskey for Heavenly Creatures.
fun_fact_3: The Best Supporting Actress award she won for The Navigator was likely also recognition of courage under fire. Peirse’s memories of a “hard but marvellous” shoot include filming in deep snow halfway up the Southern Alps, while heavily pregnant.
quote_1: [On her role in ‘Rain’] It was wonderful because most roles for women in their 40s are about serving the needs of others in terms of cups of tea and coffee.

name: Nick Blake

fun_fact_2: Nick Blake is a New Zealand actor.

name: Katie Jackson
fun_fact_1: Daughter of Peter Jackson and Fran Walsh.
fun_fact_2: Appeared in all 6 movies.

name: Richard Whiteside
fun_fact_1: Richard owned and operated a small boutique hotel named 'The Shepherds Arms' which was complete with sheep themed memorabilia including an old stuffed Rams head taking pride of place in the Restaurant. After selling his business he made the move into acting and went on to become a victim of zombie sheep by having his head eaten in the Kiwi cult classic film "Black Sheep"!.
fun_fact_2: Stood for Parliament in 2008, reducing the majority by nearly 8000 votes and narrowly missing out becoming an MP by just 700 votes.

name: Billy Connolly
fun_fact_1: Billy's Parkinson's Disease was initially diagnosed under informal circumstances in that he was approached by a doctor in his L.A. hotel lobby after an appearance on Conan O'Brien's show in 2012. After the doctor introduced himself as a fan, he then remarked that Billy's shuffling gait resembled that of someone with the possible early onset of the disease and advised him to get a medical checkup.
fun_fact_2: He is one of the UK's top comedians. Tangential storytelling in stand-up comedy performances, often featuring multilayered digressions from original story.
fun_fact_3: Known for his long, messy hair, goatee and lots of bad language in his stand-up show.
quote_1: It's very awkward to be kind of big in your own field. It limits what you're offered. People are swayed by the fact that you're a comedian or a musician or whatever they think you are. When it comes to choosing you, they get a bit shaky about offering you a different type of role. But I've really been very lucky. When you compare me to other comedians, I've been very fortunate. So you'll get no complaints.
quote_2: The future doesn't exist and neither does the past. Worrying about it is a waste of time and effort.
quote_3: I think Wilderbeest don't know that they're Wilderbeest. For there are no mirrors on the Serengeti. "Run Wilderbeest! Run for your life!" "I'm not a Wilderbeest! I'm one of those stripey things over there!"

name: Billy Jackson
fun_fact_1: He's the first son of director Peter Jackson and screenwriter Fran Walsh.
fun_fact_2: Was in 4 of the 6 movies.

name: John Tui
fun_fact_1: He has been cast in the upcoming 2021 television series, "Young Rock", telling the story of Dwayne 'The Rock' Johnson's youth and being raised around his professional wrestling family.
fun_fact_2: John is the only actor to portray the role of two different mentors that were also Power Rangers
fun_fact_3: In addition to ‘The Hobbit’, John has also been a part of other large film franchises, such as the character Korso in "Solo: A Star Wars Story" and Kal Hobbs in "Fast & Furious Presents: Hobbs & Shaw."
quote_1: Before Battleship I was doing everything from painting to building to babysitting. Money came in drips and drabs. I'm not chasing fame. For me, providing for my family is my biggest role.
quote_2: I've always been passionate about acting, whether it's Shakespeare, TV or film  and it's a craft. I love what I do and if you are an actor the most important thing you can do is to be as prepared as you can. It's that Kiwi No 8 wire mentality  give it all you've got.

name: Guillermo del Toro
fun_fact_1: Has extensive knowledge and practical experience playing video-games, and is very good friends with Japanese video-game designer/director Hideo Kojima, with whom he shares many interests, including 1960s classic movies and Japanese TV shows, and rare toys.
fun_fact_2: Was attached to direct The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey (2012) but dropped out due to repeated delays in the production and the project stalling due to MGM declaring bankruptcy. He still received screenwriting credit on the film and its sequels: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013) and The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014).
fun_fact_3: In an article in USA Today (August 22, 2011), del Toro listed his six favorite fright films: Freaks (1932), The Uninvited (1944), The Innocents (1961), Jaws (1975), Alien (1979), and The Shining (1980).
quote_1: Do whatever the fuck you want, even if it's wrong, and then tell about it with honesty. That is filmmaking to me...Success is fucking up on your own terms.
quote_2: I think that 50 percent of the narrative is in the audio/visual storytelling. I happened to think the screenplay is the basis of it all, but definitely doesn't tell the movie. It tells the story, but doesn't tell the whole movie. A lot of the narrative is in the details.
quote_3: If you're not operating on an instinctive level, you're not an artist.... Reason over emotion is bullshit, absolute bullshit... We suffocate ourselves in rules. I find fantasy liberating.

name: Sala Baker
fun_fact_1: Sala Baker is an actor and stuntman from New Zealand.
fun_fact_2: Originally hired as one of several stunt performers for The Lord of the Rings film trilogy, he ended up landing the part of the Dark Lord Sauron. In addition, he also played several Orcs, a Gondorian, and one of the Rohirrim.
fun_fact_3: Came from a very large family, 11 children!
quote_1: It was great. The good guys get the women, I'll get there one day of course, but the bad guys have so much fun. You die but you have so much fun doing it. It's like throwing yourself around and fighting the good guys – and obviously losing to the good guys – but it's a lot more fun. That was my main [reason] for doing it.
quote_2: I was a big Superman fan and collected comics.
quote_3: [On trying out for Sauron] By the end of the shoot that we had done, I had cuts and bruises and everything but I was, like, “Who cares! I’m going to make sure I look amazing in this suit.”
